trial_identification.studytitle: The Te Ira Tangata Study: In Maori who present to hospital with self harm is a complex package of interventions better than treatment as usual in preventing repetition of self harm twelve months after the index episode?
trial_identification.scientifictitle: In Maori who present to hospital with self harm is a complex package of interventions better than treatment as usual in preventing repetition of self harm twelve months after the index episode?

conditions.healthcondition: Presentation to hospital with self harm

interventions.interventions: The intervention package consists of the following elements delivered by Maori mental health workers, cultural workers and kaumatua which have some variation between cases depending on the clinical context: i) patient support - usually in the two weeks post discharge two phone calls or face to face contacts to check the discharge paln from hospital is actually happening. ii) problem solving therapy - four to six sessions of 30 to 60 minutes over four weeks iii) a cultural assessment - focusing on sense of belonging and cultural identity iv) a risk management programme for the clinicians v) postcards in the year after the attempt posted monthly after the first month vi) improved access to general practice
interventions.comparator: Treatment as usual differs on a case by case basis and is decided by the clinician who usually sees the patient. This may consist of admission to hospital, referral to a mental health crisis service, a community mental health service, their general practitioner or nothing plus a variety of less common interventions.

primaryOutcome.outcome: The proportion of participants scoring less than 9 on the Beck Hopelessness Scale at twelve months.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Three months and twelve months after the index presentation

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Repetition of self harm assessed by hospital records, national minimum dataset and self report.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Three and twelve months after the index presentation.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Depression measured on the Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Three and twelve months after the index presentation.

secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Three and twelve months after the index presentation.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Maori presenting to hospital with self harm
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Under age Out of area Unable to consent (e.g. psychotic, cognitively impaired)

trial_design.concealment: This is a Zelen trial so potential participants are randomised first and then approached to consent to whichever arm they have been allocated. Treatment allocation is determined by a remote computer at the Clinical Trials Research Unit at the University of Auckland.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Thye study is designed to answer the question "in Maori who present to hospital with self harm is a complex package of interventions delivered in a culturally acceptable way plus treatment as usual better than treatment as usual alone". The treatment package consists of several elements including patient support designed to stop patients slipping through the cracks in between hospital and community care; problem solving therapy; improved access to general practitioners; risk management for the self harm team; cultural assessment; regular postcards for a year. This is delivered in a culturally appropriate way using Maori clinicians and cultural workers with their unique networks to supplement problem solving.
